title: Eurozone recovery 'subdued and fragile'; UK deficit keeps growing - as it happened | Business | The Guardian
summary: eurozone consumer morale hits six-month low .
us manufacturing pmi hits four-year high .
bank of america reaches $ 16.65bn settlement over mortgage mis-selling .
obr : weak wage growth could hit government revenues .
uk deficit up by £ 1.8bn so far this year .
uk retail sales growth slows , as price wars rage .

documents.title: closing summary
text: that 's all for today .

here 's a recap : private sector growth across the eurozone has slowed this month , bringing job creation to a standstill and dampening hopes that europe 's weak economy will rebound robustly from its recent stagnation .
the latest monthly index of purchasing managers ( pmi ) , from data firm markit , found that france 's economy continues to struggle .
french manufacturing activity is falling at its fastest rate in 15 months .
growth in the country 's service sector did up , but the overall french private sector is flatlining after shrinking for the last three months .
the composite pmi for the eurozone fell to a two-month low of 52.8 this month , down from 53.8 in july .
factory output weakened , with the eurozone manufacturing pmi falling to a 13-month low of 50.8 , closer to the 50-point mark that separates expansion from contraction .

firms also reported that job creation had slowed to near-stagnation in august , suggesting that progress in cutting eurozone unemployment is stalling full story : slowdown in eurozone growth cools hopes that economy will bounce back eurozone composite pmi , june 2014 photograph : /markit jennifer mckeown of capital economics summed up the mood : the survey added to signs that the euro-zone 's feeble recovery is already over , increasing pressure on the ecb to do more to support the flagging economy even as other central banks start to tighten monetary policy .
the eurozone has also been hit by a drop in consumer confidence .
chinese factory growth has slowed to a three-month low , with new-order growth dropping .
hongbin qu , hsbc 's chief economist for china , said beijing should supply more policy support to help consolidate the recovery .

but america 's factory sector appears to be growing strongly this month : the us manufacturing pmi jumped to 58.0 , the highest reading since april 2010 , as companies put last winter 's slowdown behind them .
us flash factory pmi , to august 2014 photograph : /markit in the uk , the government has insisted that it is on track to hit its deficit reduction targets .
july 's public finances were weaker than expected ; a deficit of £ 200m means that the uk has borrowed £ 1.8bn more so far this year than in april-july 2013 .
british retail sales growth has slowed , as price wars between supermarkets drive down the cost of food .
and bank of america is paying almost $ 17bn to settle charges it sold flawed mortgage securities in the run up to the financial crisis - a record amount .
thanks , and good night .
gw
here 's our story about bank of america 's record-breaking settlement deal : bank of america reaches record $ 17bn settlement over questionable mortgages

documents.title: europe 's stock markets gain ground
text: european stock markets have just closed higher , helped by the strong economic data from the us and speculation that the weak european surveys will prompt fresh stimulus from the ecb .
the german dax is up almost 1 % , france 's cac gained 1.2 % , while the ftse 100 is up a more modest 0.26 % , or 13 points .

david madden of ig explains : in london , the ftse 100 eked out a small gain as a lack of negative news from eastern europe and a string of positive updates from the us have brightened the mood ; the eurozone stock markets are benefiting the most from the improved relationship with moscow .
the unimpressive services and manufacturing data from the eurozone is fuelling speculation that the european central bank will loosen its monetary policy this side of christmas .
brenda kelly ( @ brendakelly ig ) ig market wrap .

some afternoon reading - this piece by matt o'brien of the washington post makes a powerful case that europe 's economy really is in trouble : worse than the 1930s : europe 's recession is really a depression written before today 's economic data , it explains how policy failures and the restrictions of the single currency have made the eurozone one of the biggest catastrophes in economic history '' .
post here 's a flavour : just like the 1930s , europe is stuck with a fixed exchange system that does n't let them print , spend , or devalue their way out of a crisis .
but , unlike then , europe might never give it up .
it 's a fidelity to failure that even the gold bloc could n't have imagined .
and that leaves the ecb as europe 's only hope now , to be fair , the draghi-led ecb has done about as much as it can given its legal and political constraints .
but you do n't grade unemployment on a curve .
and those constraints are n't going to go away , not enough anyway , to avoid a lost decade or two .
instead , the ecb will probably keep doing the bare minimum : some half-hearted quantitative easing that will stop as soon as germany starts to grow faster .
they have made a desert , and called it the eurozone

documents.title: capital economics : eurozone 's feeble recovery is already over
text: today 's economic data underlines how the eurozone has fallen further behind the us .

jennifer mckeown of capital economics says the slowdown in the factory sector suggests geopolitics is hurting europe : the manufacturing index suffered the sharpest decline , from 52.7 to 50.9 , suggesting that the russia-ukraine crisis is having a greater impact on confidence and activity than direct trade links alone might imply .

in any event , the survey added to signs that the euro-zone 's feeble recovery is already over , increasing pressure on the ecb to do more to support the flagging economy even as other central banks start to tighten monetary policy .
note that the flash estimate of the ec 's measure of consumer confidence in august was also weaker than expected .

documents.title: eurozone consumer morale hits six-month low .
text: in another blow to the eurozone , consumer confidence in the region has fallen to a six-month low .
the eu 's index of consumer morale fell to minus 10.0 in august , dropping from july 's minus 8.4 to the lowest level since february .
confidence also dipped across the wider eu , from minus 5.5 to minus 6.4 % .
commission the ukraine crisis may have hit sentiment , as russia and the west hit each other with sanctions .
the weak growth figures in the second quarter of 2014 may also be a factor - with france stagnating , germany contracting by 0.2 % , and italy falling back into recession .
markit economics ( @ markiteconomics ) consumer confidence in the eurozone falls more than expected : down to -10.0 ( -8.4 in july ) .
analysts had expected a fall to -9.0 world first ( @ world first ) euro-area consumer sentiment drops as ukraine threatens recovery

two more upbeat pieces of us data have also been announced , as fastft explains : existing home sales climbed 2.4 per cent last month , putting activity at its strongest since october , the national association of realtors said .
separately , a measure of manufacturing around the philadelphia area expanded at the fastest pace since early 2011 .
an index from the reserve bank of philadelphia climbed to 28 , up from 23.9 and the strongest reading since march 2011 .
more here : us housing , manufacturing data tops forecasts

documents.title: us manufacturing pmi hits four-year high .
text: just in : activity in america 's factory sector has surged at the fastest rate in over four years , outpacing europe 's weak economy the flash manufacturing purchasing managers index has jumped to a reading of 58.0 in august from 55.8 in july to reach the highest level since april 2010 .
firms reported a steep rise in production , and in new work , suggesting the sector enjoyed robust growth .

here are the key points from markit :  manufacturing pmi rebounds sharply from july 's three-month low output and new orders both rise at faster rates new export business increases at steepest pace for three years employment growth accelerates to strongest since march 2013 photograph : /markit markit economist tim moore adds : overall , with job hiring gathering momentum and input buying expanding at the sharpest pace for at least seven years , it seems us manufacturers are increasingly confident that the recovery is firmly back on track and are gearing up for a sustained rebound in production schedules over the months ahead . ''
a much rosier than in france , where factory activity shrank at its fastest rate in over a year .
eric holder , united states attorney general , is telling reporters that the $ 16.65bn settlement with bank of america is the largest civil settlement with a single entity in history . ''
bloomberg news ( @ bloombergnews ) watch live : u.s. justice department press conference on bank of america settlement :

documents.title: bank of america reaches $ 16.65bn settlement over mortgage mis-selling
text: breaking : bank of america has reached a $ 16.65bn settlement with us regulators including the department of justice .
this will resolve charges that it mis-sold mortgage products in the lead-up to the financial crisis .
it is paying a cash penalty of $ 9.65bn , and an additional $ 7bn in relief to consumers .
bloomberg news ( @ bloombergnews ) breaking : bank of america agrees to pay $ 16.65 billion to end u.s. mortgage probes
marketwatch ( @ marketwatch ) u.s. jobless claims fall below 300,000 for third time in five weeks
just in - the number of new americans signing on for unemployment benefit fell by 14,000 last week , to 298,000 .
economists had expected a 12,000 drop .
and the number of 'continued claims ' ( people who 've been on the list for at least a week ) hit a seven-year low of 2.500 million .
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) u.s .
initial jobless claims fell 14,000 last week to 298,000

documents.title: obr : weak wage growth could hit government revenues
text: the treasury in london .
scarff/getty images britain 's fiscal watchdog , the office for budget responsibility , has now weighed in on this morning 's uk public finances , which showed a £ 223m deficit last month .
they point out that the uk often manages to keep its budget in surplus in july , as corporation tax and self-assessment payments often land during this month .
this time , though , underlying borrowing reached £ 800m .
the obr cites one factor : corporation tax was down 4.8 per cent on a year earlier in july , primarily because of a fall in receipts from oil and gas firms .
the watchdog also warned that britain 's weak earnings growth ( real wages are still shrinking , remember ) means that income tax and national insurance payments could suffer .
the obr explains : higher borrowing so far this year largely reflects weak receipts growth .

one-off factors such as income shifting in response to the reduction in the additional rate of income tax and last year 's swiss capital tax proceeds depressed receipts growth in the early part of the financial year .
other factors such as the end-loading of sa payments will boost receipts in january and february next year .
in addition , weaker-than-expected wage growth so far in 2014-15 is likely to affect paye and nic receipts .
and that could leave george osborne with less wriggle-room for cuts or giveaways in next march 's pre-election budget , perhaps .
here 's the full commentary from the obr
we started the morning with disappointing chinese factory growth data , from hsbc/markit .

this chart from reuters ' eric beebo shows that activity has bobbed around the 50-point no-change mark for some time : eric burroughs ( @ ericbeebo ) china pmis have been stuck clsoe to 50 for quite a while now .
basically a long period of stagnation
city firm panmure gordon is concerned that today 's public finance figures show the uk borrowing £ 1.8bn more this year than last year ( so far ) .

but there are encouraging signs for the future , they argue : there is , however , some emerging evidence of a recent in tax receipts as strong economic growth begins to be reflected in higher tax receipts .

given strong economic growth is expected to continue into the second half of the year , we see the for uk public finances gradually improving - this in turn will give the chancellor more leeway to consider a pre-election tax cut in the november autumn statement .
as flagged earlier , though , it 's vat and stamp duty that are up , rather than corporation tax receipts

a reminder of how far britain remains from george osborne 's original goal of eliminating the deficit by 2015 mike bird ( @ birdyword ) the public finances are now so far from plan a that public borrowing is twice as high as was estimated in june 2010 .

documents.title: labour : uk deficit up so far this year
text: and here 's labour 's response to the uk public sector borrowing figures : chris leslie mp , labour 's shadow chief secretary to the treasury , said : today 's public borrowing figures confirm that george osborne is set to break his promise to balance the books by next year , and on top of that so far this year he has borrowed £ 37 billion - more than the same period last year .
borrowing is now expected to be almost £ 190 billion more than planned under this government .
this is the cost of three damaging years of flatlining and falling living standards we have seen since the election .
labour will balance the books and get the national debt falling as soon as possible in the next parliament .

and we will we will do so more fairly by reforming our economy for the long-term and reversing david cameron 's top rate tax cut for the top one per cent of earners and we will act to secure a strong and balanced recovery that delivers rising living standards for the many , not just a few at the top . ''

- that target was actually abandoned a couple of year back , when it was clear that the uk economy was struggling ( due to a combination of osborne 's plan a austerity , and the eurozone crisis , as economics editor larry elliott reminded us last week )

documents.title: treasury : we 'll hit deficit target
text: the uk treasury insists that the uk is on track to hit its deficit reduction target , despite actually borrowing £ 1.8bn more this year than last year ( see 10.27am for details and the key chart ) .
a spokesperson says : today 's public sector net borrowing figures continue to be in line with the budget forecast which predicts the deficit to have halved by the end of this year .
but the job is not yet done which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy .

it does appear that the public finance figures are being distorted by one-off effects last year ( proceeds from a tax avoidance deal with switzerland , and behavioural changes '' following the cut in the top rate of tax ) .

these charts , from the independent 's ben chu , underline how uk corporation tax receipts have lagged vat and national insurance since the start of the financial crisis : ben chu ( @ benchu ) corporation tax receipts showing no signs of improvement ( unlike vat and national insurance ) : ben chu ( @ benchu ) here 's the same of relatively weak corporation tax receipts as an index :

documents.title: uk deficit up by £ 1.8bn so far this year
text: despite britain 's economic recovery , the uk government continue to borrow to balance the books .
the latest public finances show that the uk ran up a deficit of over £ 200m in july , or £ 800m if all temporary and one-off factors are stripped out .
either way , it 's around £ 800m less than a year ago , but it dashes hopes of a small surplus last month .
timesbusiness ( @ timesbusiness ) uk finances disappoint - public sector net borrowing , ex financial interventions , in deficit by £ 239m in july .
surplus of £ 50m was expected .

britain has now borrowed £ 37bn since the start of april , once you strip out the profits on the bank of england 's quantitative easing programme , and the impact of taking the royal mail pension fund into public hands .
that 's £ 1.8bn more than in april-july 2013 .
as this chart shows , that 's not the great start towards the government 's plan to lower the deficit in 2014-15 .

uk public finances , to july 2014 photograph : /ons the figures also show that tax revenues from consumer spending , share trading and house sales all rose , while corporation tax receipts fell compared to a year ago .

vat receipts increased by £ 0.4 billion ( or 3.9 % ) to £ 10.3 billion , income tax related payments increased by £ 0.8 billion ( or 5.1 % ) to £ 17.4 billion , stamp duties ( on shares , land & property ) increased by £ 0.1 billion ( or 11.7 % ) to £ 1.3 billion , while corporation tax decreased by £ 0.3 billion ( or 4.8 % ) to £ 6.6 billion .
liam tyce ( @ theequitysquare ) uk economy seizing up - july retail sales rise just 0.1 % , est .
a 0.4 % increase .
rate hikes start to look further into the distance
jamie mcgeever ( @ reutersjamie ) change in uk retail sales annual growth vs previous month down 3 months in a row for first time since 2009 :
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) inflation down , retail sales down 3 mths in row , two mpc members keeping heads down today

documents.title: uk retail sales slow : expert reaction
text: the weak uk retail sales growth ( details here ) will send concern rippling through the sector , says keith richardson of lloyds bank commercial banking .
richardson agrees that grocers are driving down prices .
he also cited england 's disappointing performance at the brazil world cup ; fans had little no excuse to celebrate with a shopping binge .
he says : a second successive month of weak sales figures will cause concern throughout the sector .
retailers will hope the slowdown in sales is a temporary blip rather than a prolonged decline in consumer confidence .
the contrasting fortunes of the food and non-food sectors was more pronounced during july .
non-food retailers , especially those operating in clothing , footwear and home improvement sectors , were boosted by a prolonged spell of good weather and a buoyant housing market .
however , food sales continue to struggle .
grocery retailers are in the midst of a price war with everyday low prices being the main strategy for both mainstream and discount operators .
while this approach has benefited consumers , the reduction in the value of goods sold will continue to have a detrimental impact on total retail sales during the forthcoming months .
england 's early exit from the world cup also deprived the grocery sector of a much needed fillip . ''

documents.title: uk retail sales growth slows , as price wars rage
text: retail sales growth across the uk has slowed last month , despite shops cutting prices as supermarkets fight for customers .
the office for national statistics reports that retail sales volumes crept up by just 0.1 % in july , compared with june .
uk retail sales , to july 2014 photograph : /ons the average prices of goods sold in july 2014 compared with july 2013 showed deflation of 0.9 % , the ons added .
food stores were the only sector to show an increase in prices ( 0.2 % ) .

it also found that the amount of money that britons spent in food stores fell by 1.3 % year-on-year in july , the first drop since records began in 1989. kit juckes ( @ kitjuckes ) uk retail sales deflators ; inc auto fuel -0.9 , ex -0.6 , non-food -0.7 , non-specialised -1.2 .

high st getting killed as price war rages shire blogger ( @ shireblogger ) # uk # retail `` july 2014 was the first time we have seen a fall in the amount spent in food stores year-on-year ( 1.3 % ) '' ons
duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) weaker than expected eurozone pmi .
q3 growth set to be around 0.3 % , essentially stagnating and little sign of recovery .

documents.title: eurozone private sector growth slows
text: growth among eurozone 's private firms is slowing this month , and at a faster rate than expected , as the region 's factories struggle .
activity across the eurozone 's manufacturing and service sectors both grew at a slower rate so far this month , data firm markit reports .
it said the eurozone recovery remains subdued and fragile '' , meaning job creation across the area came to a near stand-still this month .
markit added : economic and geopolitical uncertainties , alongside the continuing need to maintain cost competiveness , are also acting as brakes on job creation .

markit 's monthly pmi survey ( which polls purchasing managers across the region ) , showed that manufacturing activity grew at the weakest rate in over a year : 50 = the cut-off between growth and contraction .
as covered earlier in this blog , german firms reported solid growth while france 's private sector stabilised , with service sector expansion countered by yet another drop in factory output .
rob dobson , senior economist at markit , says the recovery still has n't taken hold in europe .
the eurozone economy continued to make steady progress in august , as the region looks to bounce back following the recent weaker-than-expected gdp readings for the currency union .

however , with the pmi output index slipping slightly to 52.8 , the region remains on course to register growth of only around 0.3 % -0.4 % in the third quarter , a level that is unlikely to stimulate any real turnaround in the labour market .
even before rising geopolitical headwinds began to buffet the economy , the double-digit unemployment rate prevailing in the eurozone was already excessively high .
signs are that the modest job creation of recent months has stalled in august .
there are some positive points coming out of the national data , however , with germany recording solid growth and france stabilising following a brief period of contraction .

further progress was also made outside of the big-two economies , although signs that output and new order growth slowed sharply over the month adds a cautionary note for the outlook in the periphery‟ .
geoffrey smith ( @ geoffreytsmith ) germany aug composite pmi 54.9 vs 55.7 ; mfg 52.0 vs 52.4 ; svcs 56.4 vs 56.7 ; still clearly in expansion territory ; output , orders up sharply

documents.title: markit : germany is enjoying a swift recovery
text: german composite pmi , to august 2014 photograph : /markit today 's pmi report also shows that german firms are less optimistic - some cited the looming introduction of a national minimum wage .
but markit is confident that germany is returning to growth after shrinking in the last quarter .
economist oliver kolodseike says : august 's flash results provide further encouraging news for germany 's private sector , with output and new orders rising sharply .
the pmi data available for the third quarter so far point to a swift recovery in gdp from the ground lost during the second quarter .
however , the concern is the divergent trends within the economy , with the manufacturing sector losing further momentum .
production growth was the weakest in over a year and employment was cut for the third month running .
services is meanwhile taking up some of the weakness in manufacturing , highlighted by sharp increases in business activity and new orders . ''
the full report is online here .

documents.title: german factory sector growth slows , but service sector pushes on
text: once again , germany 's companies are performing better than their french counterparts .
growth in germany 's private sector is easing this month , markit reports , with factory bosses reporting a significant slowdown .
but the germany economy still appears to be enjoying robust growth this quarter , having suffered an unexpected 0.2 % contraction in april-june .
in its new health check of the german economy , just released , markit reports that output growth has slowed slightly as manufacturing loses momentum . ''
some companies said they are suffering from bottlenecks '' in the goods producing sector .
but germany 's service sector appears to be on a roll .
new orders are up this month , at the fastest rate in nine months .
and private firms continue to take on staff - in a stark contrast with france where people are being laid off at a faster rate ( see 8.18am ) .
markit says : august 's survey results signalled a further round of job creation in germany 's private sector , extending the current period of employment growth to 10 months .
the latest increase in staffing levels was the weakest in five months .
some companies hired additional workers in response to higher order intakes .
frederik ducrozet ( @ fwred ) german resistenz reaction to follow
michael hewson ( @ mhewson cmc ) france pmi 's mixed - aug manufacturing comes in at 46.5 , but as services improves to 51.1 # euro

documents.title: early reaction
text: frederik ducrozet ( @ fwred ) `` the data point to quarterly gdp tracking around stagnation in the third quarter . ''
secular french stagnation ?
econhedge ( @ econhedge ) terrible manuf new order data in france - 44.2

documents.title: markit : france is still stagnating
text: today 's pmi report suggests the french economy is still stagnating , having failed to grow for the last six months .
jack kennedy , senior economist at markit , explains : modest expansion in france 's dominant service sector masked ongoing weakness in manufacturing during august .
overall , the data point to quarterly gdp tracking around stagnation in the third quarter , continuing the flat trend seen since the turn of the year .

an acceleration in the rate of job cutting combined with ebbing business confidence in the service sector during august offers little to suggest that the economy is set to snap out of its sluggish performance any time soon . ''
the full report is online here .
this chart shows the latest worrying increase in workers being laid off :

documents.title: french factory downturn deepens , but service sector up
text: france 's manufacturing sector is continuing to contract , dragging back private sector growth in europe 's second largest economy .
the flash french manufacturing pmi , which tracks activity across french factories sector , slipped to a 15-month low in august .
that indicates that the sector is shrinking at a faster pace this month .
the data was just released by markit .
in better news , it also reported that the french service sector is growing this month - meaning the overall private sector had stabilised in august '' , having contracted in recent months .
but france 's unemployment problems appear to be worsening , with firms cutting staff at a faster rate : employment in the french private sector fell for a tenth consecutive month in august .
moreover , the rate of job shedding quickened to the fastest since february .
lower staffing levels were recorded in the services and manufacturing sectors , with the latter posting the steeper decline .
this graph tracks the pmi ( in blue ) against french gdp ( which has not grown this year ) .
french pmi , flash , august 2014 photograph : /markit here 's the details .
any reading below 50 indicates a contraction , while a > 50 reading shows growth .

flash france composite output index rises to 50.0 ( 49.4 in july ) , 4-month high flash france services activity index rises to 51.1 ( 50.4 in july ) , 5-month high flash france manufacturing output index rises to 45.4 ( 45.2 in july ) , 2-month high flash france manufacturing pmi falls to 46.5 ( 47.8 in july ) , 15-month low reaction to follow

zhu qibing , economist at minzu securities , agrees that beijing 's government will need take more stimulus measures in the face of a slowing economy , but does n't expect monetary stimulus : definitely there will be more measures to keep growth momentum steady in coming months .
but we do n't expect interest rate cuts in the near term as the central bank has reiterated that it would keep its prudent monetary policy unchanged . ''

documents.title: gold price dips again
text: last night 's hawkish minutes from the federal reserve have pushed up the us dollar , and driven the gold price down 1.6 % to a 2-month low of $ 1,278 per ounce .
gold has already fallen for the last four days running , partly due to the strengthening us dollar .
dutch financial group rabobank has added to concerns that the ukraine crisis could hurt the european economy .
it warned this morning that sanctions imposed on russia could have an adverse effect '' on its customers , and could therefore adversely hurt its own performance .

documents.title: chinese factory growth drops to three-month low
text: fears that the chinese economy is faltering have been fanned by new manufacturing data overnight , showing that growth has dropped to the lowest rate since may .
output and new orders across its huge factory sector have both slowed in august , suggesting the economy has softened .
and companies laid off staff at a faster rate , according to hsbc and markit 's monthly report .
the hsbc/markit flash china manufacturing purchasing managers ' index ( pmi ) fell to 50.3 from july 's 18-month high of 51.7 .
that was some way short of analyst forecasts of 51.5 , and close to the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction .

/markit hongbin qu , chief economist for china at hsbc , says the data suggests the momentum of china 's recovery has slowed , adding ; we think more policy support is needed to help consolidate the recovery .
both monetary and fiscal policy should remain accommodative until there is a more sustained rebound in economic activity . ''
here 's the full breakdown , showing how growth slowed - and that prices also dropped ( suggesting deflationary pressure are growing too ) .
/markit

documents.title: manufacturing data to shed light on french woes
text: good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the economy , the financial markets , the eurozone and business .
we 're about to get a fresh health-check on the eurozone economy , and it may not be too cheering .
it 's that time of the month when markit , the data provider , gives its first estimate at how companies across the globe are faring .
and economists expect to hear that france 's private sector is still struggling , pulling back the wider eurozone economy .
the french manufacturing pmi ( or purchasing managers index ) is expected to show another contraction , while its service sector may manage a little growth .
it 's released at 8am bst .
germany 's private firms are expected to have performed better ( data at 8.30am ) , but markit could still report a slowing in private sector growth across the eurozone compared with july , at 9am .
that would be worrying , given the eurozone recovery hit the rails in the last quarter , failing to grow at all .
in the uk , we get new public sector borrowing figures , for july , and the latest retail sales data too .
there 'll be american data too - the weekly jobless data , and markit 's first stab at the us manufacturing pmi for august .
elsewhere today the european markets are digesting the minutes of the federal reserve 's latest monetary policy committee meeting , released last night .
they were more hawkish than expected , showing that fed policymakers discussed how to communicate a future rate rise .
i 'm afraid it looks rather quiet otherwise - the summer lull is upon us .
but i 'll be tracking the key developments through the day

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial news, as private sector growth in the eurozone slows and job creation grinds to a halt.
French factory activity drops, as economy stagnates.
